> The **(Kolmogorov–Sinai) entropy rate** of a dissipative, chaotic system is often interpreted as the rate (in bits per second) at which information about the initial conditions is **lost** (or equivalently, the rate at which new “information” is generated from the perspective of unpredictability).

In the Lorenz system (with the classic parameters \(\sigma = 10\), \(\beta = 8/3\), \(\rho = 28\)), we have a strange attractor that exhibits sensitive dependence on initial conditions (i.e., chaos). A typical value for the largest Lyapunov exponent is around \(0.9\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\), and the **entropy rate** (closely related to the sum of positive Lyapunov exponents) ends up being on the order of 1 bit/s (this can vary a bit depending on the exact definitions and parameter choices, but it is in that ballpark).

---

## 1. What does “bits/second of information about initial conditions are lost” mean?

If a system has an entropy rate \(h\) bits/s, that means that **any two initially close states** will, on average, separate so quickly that you lose your ability to distinguish them at a rate of \(h\) bits per second. 

- **Losing bits**: You can think of “losing bits” as follows. Suppose you only know the initial state to \(B\) bits of precision. Because small errors get exponentially magnified, after a certain time \(T\approx B/h\) seconds, that finite precision is exhausted; your uncertainty in the state of the system becomes of order 1 (i.e., you basically lose predictive power of the exact trajectory). 
- **Gaining unpredictability**: Another way to say the same thing is that if you attempt to *track* the system’s state, each second requires you to refine your knowledge of the initial condition by another \(h\) bits if you want to keep predicting accurately. 

In short, an entropy rate \(h\) means your initial-condition “budget” of precision (in bits) is “used up” at \(h\) bits per second by the exponential divergence of nearby trajectories.

---

## 2. How many bits do you need at \(t = 0\)?

### If you want to predict the system forever

- **Infinite time horizon**: Strictly speaking, if you want to predict the Lorenz system (or any chaotic system) *forever*, you would need *infinitely many* bits of precision in specifying the initial condition. That is because any finite number of bits eventually becomes insufficient, once exponential divergence has had enough time to act.

### If you only need to predict for a finite time \(T\)

- **Finite time horizon**: If you only want to track the system up to time \(T\), then you need roughly \(B = T \times h\) bits of precision in your initial condition. So with an entropy rate of, say, 1 bit/s, you would need about 10 bits of initial precision to be confident of your prediction for 10 s, 100 bits for 100 s, etc.

Hence at \(t=0\), the *practical* number of bits you “need” depends on *how long* into the future you want accurate predictions. But for an unbounded time horizon, you need infinitely many bits—chaos does not permit perfect infinite-time prediction from any finite-precision initial state.

---

## 3. What about \(t \to \infty\)?

As \(t\) becomes very large, **the system “forgets”** the initial condition altogether. In a *dissipative* chaotic system like Lorenz,

- The volume in phase space contracts (it’s “dissipative”), so trajectories are pulled onto a lower-dimensional attractor.
- **On the attractor**, there is sensitive dependence (chaos), so nearby states get stretched apart (even though overall volume is shrinking in the full phase space).
- Eventually, *no matter how precisely* you knew the initial condition, the trajectory “mixes” on the attractor enough that you can’t recover the initial details. That is the essence of saying that the system has *lost information* about its initial condition.

Once the system has evolved a long time, every initial condition “looks alike” in terms of the long-term statistical behavior on the attractor (though, of course, the precise phase of the motion can still differ if you somehow carried infinite precision).

In other words:

- **At \(t \to \infty\)**, if you look at the system on its chaotic attractor, it no longer “knows” (and you no longer know) which exact initial condition led there. All states “scramble” into a certain invariant distribution on the attractor. 
- This is why we say the system has an **entropy rate**: it is actively *destroying* memory (bits) of where it started, pushing trajectories into the chaotic set whose fine details are exponentially sensitive and effectively randomize the trajectory over long times.

---

## 4. Putting this all together intuitively

1. **At \(t=0\)**:
   - To predict indefinitely, you’d need *infinitely many* bits to nail down the initial condition. Otherwise, chaos wins after some finite time.
   - If you only want to predict up to some finite time \(T\), you need about \(h \times T\) bits. 

2. **As \(t \to \infty\)**:
   - The Lorenz system (like many dissipative chaotic systems) approaches its attractor and effectively “forgets” the initial condition. Any finite difference in the initial state is overshadowed by the chaotic mixing.
   - From the system’s own point of view, all those bits about the initial condition have been “lost” (they are no longer recoverable from the state at large \(t\)).

This is precisely what is meant by saying “the system loses \(\,h\) bits of information per second about the initial condition.” Every second, another \(\,h\) bits of your initial-precision budget are eroded by the exponential divergence on the attractor. 

---

### Lorenz Example Highlights

- **Largest Lyapunov exponent** is roughly \(0.9\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\).  
- **Entropy rate** is on the order of 1 bit/s.  

Thus, \(\approx 1\) bit of your initial-condition knowledge is effectively wiped out every second. After \(T\) seconds, you have lost \(T\) bits. If you started with only \(T\) bits, you are now “in the dark” about the specific phase of the system’s trajectory; it becomes unpredictable beyond that horizon.

Hence:

- **At \(t=0\)** (for indefinite time) \(\rightarrow\) “You need infinite bits.”  
- **At \(t=0\)** (for time \(T\)) \(\rightarrow\) “You need \(T \times h\) bits.”  
- **As \(t \to \infty\)** \(\rightarrow\) “All those bits get irretrievably lost to the chaotic evolution; the system on its attractor no longer distinguishes initial states.”  

That is the intuitive heart of the statement that the entropy rate measures how many bits per second of initial-condition information a chaotic, dissipative system is losing.

First, let’s clarify the two concepts in question:

2. **Entropy rate (bits/second)** and information loss about initial conditions:

   - For a chaotic system, you lose a certain number of bits of precision *per unit time* because trajectories separate exponentially in at least one direction of phase space.

They are *related* in the sense that both talk about the “size” or “description” of a system, but **they measure fundamentally different aspects**:

---

## 1. Dimension is about the *static* coordinate count

The dimension of the state space tells you *how many real numbers* you need to specify a single instantaneous state:

- If your system is \(d\)-dimensional, you need \(d\) real coordinates (like \(d=3\) for Lorenz).
- Each real coordinate, in principle, can require infinitely many bits to specify exactly (since a real number is uncountably many possible values).

This means if you tried to store an *exact* initial condition, you need infinitely many bits anyway—simply because real numbers are infinitely precise. In practice, you pick some finite *precision* if you want to do simulations or predictions (e.g., 32-bit floats, 64-bit doubles, etc.).

---

## 2. Entropy rate is about the *time evolution* and *loss of precision*

The entropy rate \(h\) (in bits/s) tells you how quickly your finite‐precision knowledge of the initial condition *evaporates* due to the exponential divergence of nearby trajectories:

- If \(h=1\) bit/s, then every second you effectively “use up” 1 bit of your initial‐condition precision just by letting the system evolve.
- This is *not* about how many coordinates you had to specify initially (that is the dimension); rather, it is about how quickly small errors in *whatever coordinates you do have* get magnified.

Hence, the number of dimensions merely says, “We have 3 (or \(d\)) coordinates.” The *entropy rate* says, “Those coordinates are diverging from each other in certain directions at some exponential rate, so you lose so many bits of your initial knowledge per second.”

---

## 3. Why they can appear unrelated (or “orthogonal”)

- You could have a *high‐dimensional* system (many degrees of freedom) that is **not** chaotic (all Lyapunov exponents negative or zero). The entropy rate would be *zero* despite having many coordinates to specify.
- You could have a *low‐dimensional* system (like Lorenz with \(d=3\)) that *is* chaotic and has a *positive* entropy rate. You lose bits of precision over time even though you only have 3 coordinates to specify.

In other words, **dimension** is basically the *count of degrees of freedom*, while **entropy rate** is how the system *dynamically “shreds” or “forgets”* the information contained in those degrees of freedom.

---

## 4. The “precision budget” vs. “number of coordinates”

To predict a chaotic system (like Lorenz) for a long time \(T\), you need:
- A *finite number of coordinates* (3 in the Lorenz case)  
- But *a lot of bits of precision* in each coordinate if you want to track the trajectory accurately for a long time.

Because the system has an entropy rate \(h\approx 1\) bit/s (roughly), if you want to be accurate out to \(T\) seconds, you need \(h \cdot T \) bits of precision *in total*—spread across whatever coordinate representation you’re using.

Yet the fact that it’s a 3D system (rather than 2D or 10D) only tells you *how many real values* you’re tracking, not how *fast* those real values become sensitive to initial differences.

---

## 5. Summary

- **Phase‐space dimension** answers the question: “How many independent real variables must I specify to pick out a single point/state in the system?”
- **Entropy rate** answers the question: “Once I pick such a state, at what speed (bits/s) does the system’s chaos erase the memory of how precisely I chose that state?”

They certainly interact—because chaos typically happens if there is at least one positive Lyapunov exponent and a well-defined dimension to the system—but they are “orthogonal” concepts in that one is a topological/geometric count (the dimension of the space) and the other is a dynamical measure (the exponential rate at which nearby trajectories diverge and erase information).

parts:
Let’s unpack the question in detail, because it touches on several different notions—(1) the geometric dimension of the Lorenz system (3D), (2) the fractal (or attractor) dimension (\(\approx 2.06\)), (3) the entropy (or Lyapunov) rate (\(\approx 1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\)), and (4) the total bits needed to store or predict states over long times. It is easy to mix these together in a way that sounds plausible but is not quite correct.

---

## 1. What you are proposing

You wrote something like:

> 1. Initially, to store a single state \(\mathbf{x}(0)\) in a \(d\)-dimensional system with \(b\) bits per coordinate, I need \(d\,b\) bits total.  
> 2. Over a long time \(T\), I would need \(d(T)\, b(T)\) bits, which you propose might be something like \(\;d_{\mathrm{attractor}} \times h \times T \approx 2.06 \times 1 \times T\;\) bits.

In other words, the second statement suggests that after time \(T\), the total bits required somehow become the product of (fractal dimension) \(\times\) (entropy rate) \(\times\) (time). Let’s see why that does **not** quite work out the way one might hope.

---

## 2. Where the confusion arises

### (a) **Dimension** vs. **bits per coordinate**

- **Dimension** (3 for the Lorenz state space) tells you how many real numbers you need to specify a single instantaneous state of \((x,y,z)\).  
- A **fractal dimension** (about 2.06 for the classic Lorenz attractor) tells you something about the geometry of the *invariant set* to which trajectories converge. It does *not* reduce the number of coordinates from 3 down to 2.06 in any practical sense. In other words, you cannot simply say, “Now I only need to store 2.06 coordinates.” You *still* store a point in \(\mathbb{R}^3\); that point just happens to lie on a fractal subset of measure zero in \(\mathbb{R}^3\).

Hence, if you want \(b\) bits of precision *per coordinate* and you have 3 coordinates, you are indeed talking about \(3b\) bits for one full state—even if the attractor’s dimension is 2.06.  

### (b) **Entropy rate** (in bits/second)

- The Kolmogorov–Sinai (KS) entropy rate \(h\) \(\approx 1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\) for the Lorenz system means: *per second*, you “lose” about 1 bit of information about the initial condition (or equivalently, you would need to “refresh” 1 bit of precision if you want to track the evolving state accurately).  
- **Crucially**, \(h\) is *not* multiplied by the dimension of the attractor to get “total bits.”  The dimension is a geometry concept, while \(h\) is a *time rate* of information loss (or unpredictability growth). They measure different things.

---

## 3. How many bits do you “need” initially vs. after time \(T\)?

### If you want to predict perfectly forever

1. **At \(t = 0\)**:  
   - Strictly, you need *infinitely many* bits if you want to track the system *forever* (because any finite precision eventually gets ruined by chaos).  
   - In practice, you pick some large but finite precision \(b\) bits/coordinate if you only want to track for some finite horizon.

2. **Over time**:  
   - The system’s **entropy rate** \(h \approx 1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\) means that *every second* you effectively lose 1 bit of your *initial-condition* precision due to exponential sensitivity. After \(T\) seconds, you’ve lost \(h\,T \approx T\) bits of whatever you started with.  
   - This *doesn’t* say you need “\(\mathrm{dimension}\times h \times T\)” bits. Rather, it says if you started with \(B\) bits of total precision (summing over the 3 coordinates), then after time \(T\), you will have effectively only \(B - hT\) bits left that still matter for distinguishing the state (if \(B - hT\) goes below zero, you have *no ability* to predict which of many states on the attractor you’re in).

### The fractal dimension *does not* multiply with the entropy rate

One might see the fractal dimension \(d_{\mathrm{fractal}}\) in other contexts (e.g., partial relationships between Lyapunov exponents and dimension, known as the **Kaplan–Yorke conjecture**). But that dimension is not something you multiply by \(h\) to figure out “how many bits you need at time \(T\).”  

In fact, the Kaplan–Yorke formula typically says something like:

\[
d_{\mathrm{KY}} \;=\; 
j \;+\; \frac{\sum_{i=1}^j \lambda_i}{|\lambda_{j+1}|}
\]

where \(\lambda_i\) are Lyapunov exponents (ordered from largest to smallest), and \(j\) is the largest index for which the sum of the first \(j\) exponents is still positive. That dimension (which for Lorenz is around 2.06) is about the geometry of the attractor, *not* how many bits you must store per second.

---

## 4. What is correct to say?

1. **To store one state** at \(t=0\), if your system is 3D and you want \(b\) bits of precision for each coordinate, you need \(3 \times b\) bits. (No mention of fractal dimension here—because you are still specifying a point \((x_0, y_0, z_0)\in\mathbb{R}^3\).)

2. **To track/predict for time \(T\)** (with a given error tolerance):
   - You would eventually need to “refine” your knowledge (or keep your knowledge from degrading) at roughly \(h\) bits per second if you want to keep the same accuracy as time goes on. Because chaos with entropy rate \(h\) is *spending your initial precision budget* at a rate of \(h\) bits/s.  
   - Thus, after time \(T\), you have effectively lost \(hT\) bits from your initial condition. If your initial condition was known to \(B\) bits, you’re left with \(B - hT\). That does *not* involve the factor 2.06.

3. **The fractal dimension** (about 2.06 for Lorenz) is a statement about how, in the long run, the set of accessible states is restricted to a fractal subset in \(\mathbb{R}^3\). It does *not* reduce the dimension you must use to specify a point in practice; you do not physically type “2.06 floating values.” You still type (or store) 3 floating‐point numbers \((x,y,z)\). The fact that the “true” orbit is on a fractal set only shows up in advanced geometric/dynamical measures (e.g. correlation dimension, capacity dimension).

Hence, **it is not correct** to multiply \(d_{\mathrm{attractor}}\approx 2.06\) by the entropy rate \(\approx 1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\) and by time \(T\) to say you need \(\approx 2.06\,T\) bits to track states at long times. That conflates two different measures:

- \(d_{\mathrm{attractor}}\): a geometric (fractal) dimension of the set of long‐term orbits.  
- \(h\): the dynamical rate (bits/s) of information destruction regarding initial conditions.

---

## 5. Takeaway

- **Dimension**: Tells you how many coordinates (still 3 for Lorenz) and is unaffected by the fractal or attractor dimension for practical “storage.”  
- **Entropy rate** (\(\approx 1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\)): Tells you how fast your knowledge of the *exact initial condition* decays over time.  
- **Fractal dimension** (\(\approx 2.06\)): A measure of the geometrical complexity of the attractor in phase space.

They do not combine in a simple product \(d_{\mathrm{attractor}}\,\times h\,\times T\) to yield the number of bits you need for large \(T\). If you want to keep predicting accurately for time \(T\), the best rule of thumb is simply:

\[
\text{**Bits needed**} \;\approx\; \bigl[\text{bits of precision you want initially}\bigr] \;+\; \bigl(h \times T\bigr),
\]

i.e.\ your *initial* precision plus an additional “\(\mathrm{entropy\,rate}\times\mathrm{time}\)” buffer to account for the ongoing loss of track due to chaotic divergence. The fractal dimension doesn’t enter directly into that formula.

I'm thinking through how the fractal dimension and positive Lyapunov exponents from the Kaplan-Yorke formula don't simplify into a direct bit-count after time T.

First, it is absolutely true that the Lorenz attractor has a fractal (Kaplan–Yorke) dimension around 2.06, which is *less* than the embedding space dimension of 3. Intuitively, this tells us that “the set of all long‐term states” (the attractor) is thinner than a 3D volume—despite living in a nominally 3D phase space. 

Where the subtleties arise is how that fractal dimension does (or does not) translate into “how many independent variables” or “how many bits” you need to encode a point on the attractor, especially when we also bring in the concept of *entropy rate* (in bits/s). Let’s separate a few different statements carefully:

---

## 1. Why fractal dimension *does* matter for storing or encoding states on the attractor

- **Covering / box‐counting argument**:  
  If you look only at states on the attractor and you want to specify a point on that attractor to within some spatial tolerance \(\varepsilon\), you might ask: “How many little boxes of side \(\varepsilon\) are needed to cover the attractor?”  

  - If the attractor has fractal dimension \(d_f\), then the number \(N(\varepsilon)\) of such boxes grows like  
    \[
      N(\varepsilon)\; \sim\; \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{\,d_f}}.
    \]  
  - Encoding which of those boxes you are in takes roughly \(\log_2 \bigl(N(\varepsilon)\bigr) \approx d_f \,\log_2\!\bigl(1/\varepsilon\bigr)\) bits.

- **So if you only care about states on the attractor** (i.e., ignoring any transient phase that has not yet settled onto the attractor), you indeed need *fewer* bits than if you had to encode a point anywhere in the full 3D volume.  
  - A purely 3D volume of side length \(L\) might require \(\sim 3 \log_2(L / \varepsilon)\) bits of resolution,  
  - while the fractal attractor requires \(\sim d_f \log_2(1/\varepsilon)\) bits for small boxes, with \(d_f \approx 2.06 < 3\).  

Hence in that sense, *if your system’s state is guaranteed to lie on the Lorenz attractor*, you do not need “3 independent degrees of freedom” to label each possible state with resolution \(\varepsilon\). The fractal dimension is relevant and lowers the asymptotic “number of bits needed to specify a typical point on the attractor.”

---

## 2. Why this does *not* trivially give you \(d_f\times h\times T\) bits over time

### (a) Fractal dimension vs. entropy rate measure different things

- **Fractal dimension** (\(d_f \approx 2.06\) for Lorenz) is a *static* property of the attractor’s geometry in phase space. It tells us how sets of size \(\varepsilon\) scale if we want to cover the attractor. 
- **Entropy rate** (\(h \approx 1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\) for Lorenz) is a *dynamic* property that tells us how fast small differences in initial conditions get amplified (or how fast information about those initial conditions is “forgotten”). 

They are connected in deep ways (e.g., through the **Kaplan–Yorke conjecture**), but you *cannot* just multiply them to get “the bits needed after time \(T\).”

### (b) You still evolve in a 3D flow—and all coordinates matter dynamically

Even though the long‐term set is fractal with dimension ~2.06, the flow is defined in \(\mathbb{R}^3\). You typically integrate  
\[
  \frac{dx}{dt} = \sigma(y - x), \quad
  \frac{dy}{dt} = x(\rho - z) - y, \quad
  \frac{dz}{dt} = xy - \beta z,
\]  
in a 3D representation \((x,y,z)\). Numerically, you do not reduce it to “2.06 floating coordinates.” You still have 3 state variables (the fractal dimension is *not* an integer sub‐space dimension). 

> *But*, if you only ever allow \(\mathbf{x}(t)\) to lie on the attractor, in principle you **can** compress your representation of \(\mathbf{x}\) below 3 real coordinates, *on average*. That is the sense in which the fractal dimension indicates “fewer degrees of freedom” in the *long‐term set*.  

### (c) The role of entropy rate in “bits lost per unit time”

Once on the attractor, each second of evolution *destroys* about \(h\) bits of initial‐condition information. This is about *dynamical unpredictability*, not about the static geometry of how the attractor sits in \(\mathbb{R}^3\). Even if the attractor were 2D, 2.06D, or 10D, the system could still have a certain *entropy rate* that says how quickly those states diverge.

---

## 3. Putting them together: “Dimension is relevant, but watch how you count bits”

1. **Static bit‐count** (for a single snapshot on the attractor to within \(\varepsilon\)):  
   \[
     \text{Bits needed} \;\approx\; 
     d_f \,\log_2 \!\bigl(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\bigr) 
     \quad (\text{where } d_f\approx 2.06).
   \]  
   That’s fewer than \(3 \,\log_2(1/\varepsilon)\) because the attractor is a fractal subset in 3D.

2. **Dynamic bit‐count** (for predicting or tracking over time \(T\)):  
   - The *entropy rate* \(h\approx 1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\) tells you that you “use up” or “lose” about 1 bit of your *initial‐condition* precision per second.  
   - If you want to maintain a certain predictive accuracy over a time \(T\), you might say you need an additional \(\approx h \times T\) bits to keep pace with the exponential divergence of nearby states.  
   - The fractal dimension *doesn’t directly multiply* the entropy rate. They are connected via formulas like  
     \[
       d_\text{Kaplan–Yorke} 
       \;=\; j \;+\; \frac{\sum_{i=1}^j \lambda_i}{\bigl|\lambda_{j+1}\bigr|}
       \quad (\text{where the sum of Lyapunov exponents up to } j \text{ is positive}),
     \]  
     but that does not yield “\(\mathrm{dimension}\times\mathrm{entropy\_rate}\times T\).”

3. **Yes, fractal dimension *is* relevant**  
   - If your question is: “How many bits do I need to store the *long‐term states* (with some precision) for a *single snapshot* once on the attractor?” then the fractal dimension is precisely what lets you compress from 3 to about 2.06 “degrees of freedom.”  
   - If your question is: “How fast do I lose track of which state I’m in (within that fractal set) as time evolves?” that is an entropy‐rate question. You can’t simply multiply them for a direct formula in bits/time.

---

## 4. An experimental viewpoint

You mentioned “You could run an experiment to verify that the fractal dimension means fewer than 3 independent variables to specify a point.” Indeed, one can do something like:

1. **Generate many states** on the Lorenz attractor (say, from a numerical simulation).  
2. **Estimate minimal number of bits** to encode those states to a certain accuracy \(\varepsilon\).  
3. You’ll find that the required bits scales more like \(d_f \log_2(1/\varepsilon)\) than \(3 \log_2(1/\varepsilon)\).  

That is consistent with the statement that the *invariant set* is fractal of dimension ~2.06.  

But then, if you evolve those points forward in time and ask “How quickly do nearby points become indistinguishable (from the standpoint of which box they end up in)?” you are invoking the *entropy rate*. That is a *time‐based* measure, not a direct extension of “we only have 2.06 coordinate degrees of freedom.”

---

## 5. Summary

- **Yes, fractal dimension *does* reduce the effective degrees of freedom** for describing *where* the system is on the attractor (i.e., a static or snapshot perspective). You really do need fewer bits on average than a full 3D covering.  
- **No, it does *not* get simply multiplied by the entropy rate** to yield “how many bits you need at time \(T\).” The entropy rate is about how quickly initial‐condition distinctions are lost; the fractal dimension is about how the set of all possible states is geometrically laid out in phase space.

In other words, the fractal dimension is certainly *not irrelevant.* It is quite meaningful if the system is strictly confined to its chaotic attractor (i.e., after transients). It tells you how large the “manifold” of possible states is in an information‐theoretic sense (on average). But be careful not to mix that static measure (\(\sim d_f\)) with the dynamical measure (\(\sim h\)) in a naive product. They each have their own domain of relevance:

1. **Fractal dimension** \(\rightarrow\) “How many bits to locate a point on the attractor to within \(\varepsilon\)?”  
2. **Entropy rate** \(\rightarrow\) “How many bits per second are needed (or lost) to keep track of divergences in time?”

Both are correct and important—just aimed at different questions.

Below is one way to think carefully about your question:

> **Question restated:**  
> “If I take a bunch of arbitrary 3D initial conditions for the Lorenz system and evolve them for a (sufficiently large) time \(T\) until they lie on (or very close to) the *chaotic attractor*, then to store (compress) the *final* 3D positions with the same accuracy as using 32‐bit floats for each coordinate, how many bits do I really need, given that the attractor has fractal dimension \(\approx 2.06\)?”

In other words, if *naïvely* I would store each final point as three 32‐bit floats (for a total of \(3 \times 32 = 96\) bits), can the *fractal* nature of the attractor reduce that “96 bits” requirement?

---

## 1. Why fractal dimension reduces *static* storage requirements

### (a) A *fractal* attractor is a “thin” subset of \(\mathbb{R}^3\)

- The Lorenz system nominally evolves in 3D space \((x,y,z)\).  
- However, once transients die out, *all* the long‐term points lie on a fractal attractor of (Kaplan–Yorke) dimension \(\,d_f \approx 2.06\).  

Because this set has a dimension *less than* 3, it “occupies” less volume in 3D. Concretely:

1. If you only care about final states on this attractor (i.e., ignoring initial transients), you do *not* need to allow *all* possible points in the bounding 3D region.  
2. Instead, you only need to encode positions *within* a fractal set of dimension \(d_f\approx 2.06\).

### (b) Box‐counting / covering argument

A standard information‐theory viewpoint says:

- To cover a fractal set of dimension \(d_f\) with small boxes of side \(\varepsilon\), you need on the order of 
  \[
    N(\varepsilon) \;\sim\; \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{\,d_f}}
  \]  
  boxes.

- Thus, if you want to label which of those boxes the point falls in, you need 
  \[
    \log_2\!\bigl[N(\varepsilon)\bigr] 
    \;\approx\; d_f \,\log_2\!\bigl(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\bigr) 
    \quad
    (\text{bits})
  \]
  of information.

By contrast, if you had to cover a *3D* region fully, you would need
\[
  N_{\text{3D}}(\varepsilon)
  \;\sim\;
  \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{\,3}}
  \quad \text{and} \quad
  \log_2\bigl[N_{\text{3D}}(\varepsilon)\bigr]
  \;=\;
  3\,\log_2 \!\bigl(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\bigr)
  \quad (\text{bits}).
\]

Hence using knowledge that the states lie on a fractal attractor of dimension \(\approx2.06\) can, in principle, reduce your storage by a factor of \(\frac{2.06}{3}\approx 0.69\).

---

## 2. Mapping \(\varepsilon\) to “32‐bit precision”

When you say “32‐bit precision for each coordinate,” one loose interpretation is:

- Each of the 3 coordinates is stored in a single‐precision float (which is 32 bits wide).  
- That effectively means \(\sim 2^{32}\) possible levels of resolution along each coordinate’s range—though floating‐point has subtleties (sign bit, exponent, etc.).  

For a rough bounding‐box size \(L\), we might treat “32 bits of precision” as picking one of \(\sim 2^{32}\) steps across length \(L\), so the “grid spacing” is \(\varepsilon \sim L / 2^{32}\). 

If we purely wanted an \(\varepsilon\)-resolution for the *attractor* in 3D, naïvely you’d say “that’s \(3 \log_2(\frac{1}{\varepsilon})\approx3\times32=96\) bits.” But factoring in the fractal dimension \(d_f\approx2.06\), you can estimate:

\[
\text{Bits needed to label a point on the attractor to resolution }\varepsilon
  \;\approx\;
  d_f\,\log_2\!\Bigl(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\Bigr).
\]

Hence if \(\varepsilon\sim L/2^{32}\), that works out to roughly

\[
   2.06 \;\times\; \log_2(2^{32})
   \;=\;
   2.06 \;\times\; 32 
   \;\approx\;
   66\,\text{bits}.
\]

So in principle, *instead of 96 bits* (3 floats) you *could* store the final state with about 66 bits if you had a perfect fractal‐aware compression scheme. 

> **Answer (in ideal theory):**  
> Around \(\,66\,\) bits are needed—*not* 96—to specify the final point on the attractor with the same \(\varepsilon\)-scale resolution you would get from 3 × 32‐bit floats.

---

## 3. Caveats & real‐world notes

1. **You need a “fractal‐aware” codec.**  
   Actually *achieving* that perfect \(\approx66\)-bit compression requires sophisticated methods that exploit the fractal geometry. You cannot just store raw \((x,y,z)\) in standard float format and expect an automatic 66‐bit usage. You would do some transform or fractal coordinate system that indexes the attractor’s set efficiently.

2. **Large vs. small transients.**  
   If *any* initial conditions are allowed (i.e. including those not on the attractor), your final state *might* not be fully on the attractor if \(T\) isn’t large enough, or if you sample during transients, etc. Then you might need more than \(d_f \log_2(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon})\) bits.  
   - If you really do wait a long time so that *every* trajectory is effectively on the attractor, that is the scenario where fractal dimension helps you.

3. **Floating‐point “32 bits” is not purely a 1D uniform discretization.**  
   In practice, single precision covers an enormous range with about 23 bits of mantissa and 8 bits of exponent (plus sign bit). The “effective \(\varepsilon\)” depends on the magnitude of the numbers, etc. But from a purely *information‐theoretic* viewpoint, you can still approximate that each float coordinate is \(\sim32\) bits of storage overall.

4. **Entropy rate is a *different* question.**  
   You might also ask, “How fast do I lose bits if I want to predict the final state from the initial conditions?” Then the **KS entropy** (\(\approx1\,\mathrm{bit/s}\)) tells you about *dynamical unpredictability*, not about how many bits are needed to *static‐store* final states lying on a fractal. (They are related via the Kaplan–Yorke formula, but not by a simple product.)

---

## 4. Short answer

- **Naïve approach**: Store final \((x,y,z)\) each as 32‐bit float \(\Rightarrow\) **96 bits** total.  
- **Using fractal dimension**: Because the Lorenz attractor has dimension \(\approx2.06\), you need about
  \[
    2.06 \;\times\; 32 \;\approx\; 66\,\text{bits}
  \]
  to achieve the *same effective spatial resolution* on the attractor.  

Thus, *in principle,* you can compress final states from 3D down to about “2D’s worth” of coordinates without losing accuracy—simply because the set of possible final points is fractal. That is where the fractal dimension matters if your only goal is to store the *endpoint* in a minimal‐bit representation.

Let’s clarify what it means to “lose precision” (or “lose bits”) while the system evolves, and how that differs from the question of how many bits are required to *store* the final state once you have it:

---

## 1. Two Notions of “Bits” in a Chaotic System

1. **Bits of Initial‐Condition *Knowledge***  
   - In a chaotic system, small uncertainties in the initial condition grow exponentially.  
   - The Kolmogorov–Sinai (KS) **entropy rate** \(h\) (bits/second) tells you how quickly you “use up” (or lose) your initial‐condition precision. After time \(T\), you have effectively lost \(h\,T\) bits of the original information about your initial state—meaning any finite precision you started with eventually becomes insufficient to predict exact trajectories.  

2. **Bits Required to *Store* a Final State**  
   - Once the system has evolved to time \(T\), you have a specific point \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) in phase space.  
   - If you want to store or transmit *that* final point with some fixed spatial resolution (say, “the same accuracy as a 32‐bit float”), you are looking at how many bits it takes to label that final point *in phase space*.  
   - This is where the **fractal dimension** of the attractor can lower the cost, because the set of all possible final states (after transients) is confined to a fractal of dimension \(d_f < 3\).  

Crucially, **losing bits of initial‐condition knowledge** is about *dynamical unpredictability over time*; it doesn’t automatically reduce (or increase) the bits you need to *encode* a final snapshot, if you already *know* (or have numerically computed) that final snapshot.

---

## 2. “Losing Precision” vs. Storing the Final State

- **If the question is**: “How many bits of precision in the *initial condition* must I carry forward if I want to predict the final state with 32‐bit accuracy after time \(T\)?”  
  - Then the answer involves the entropy rate: Because chaos amplifies small errors, you might need *more* than 32 bits of initial precision (per coordinate) to end up with 32 bits of accuracy at time \(T\). Roughly speaking, you lose about \(h\,T\) bits to exponential divergence, so you must start with \(\text{(32 bits)} + (h\,T)\) bits (in total) if you do not want your final coordinate to degrade below 32 bits.  

- **If the question is**: “Once the system *is* at \(\mathbf{x}(T)\), how many bits do I need to store that point to the same spatial resolution as 3 floats?”  
  - Then the answer involves the fractal dimension \(d_f\). Because the *set* of all possible \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) (for large \(T\)) sits on a fractal of dimension \(d_f\approx2.06\), in principle you can compress each final point to about
    \[
      d_f \,\log_2\!\bigl(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\bigr)
    \]
    bits, rather than \(3\,\log_2(1/\varepsilon)\). In float‐like terms, that might drop from a naive 96 bits (3×32) down to \(\approx66\) bits if you do perfect fractal‐based compression.

These are *two distinct issues*:

1. **Maintaining predictive accuracy** while the system evolves (you “lose bits” to chaos).  
2. **Encoding the final location** on the attractor (you can “save bits” via fractal geometry).

---

## 3. Why “Losing Bits” Doesn’t Contradict “Fewer Bits to Store the Final State”

- **Chaotic “loss of bits”** refers to irreversibility and unpredictability from the perspective of the initial condition. You cannot recover fine details of the initial condition from the final state. You also cannot reliably predict the final state from a low‐precision initial condition once the system has evolved a while.  
- **Fewer bits to store** the final state simply recognizes that the *long‐term* set of all possible states is a fractal of dimension \(<3\). So *if you already have* (or measure) the final state precisely, you can index it in fewer bits than it would take to store an arbitrary point in 3D.  

Hence, the fact that “you lose bits while evolving” (in the sense of chaotic sensitivity) doesn’t negate the fact that, once the system is *on* the attractor at time \(T\), you only need \(\approx d_f\log_2(1/\varepsilon)\) bits to specify which point it ended up at—because the system can’t be *everywhere* in 3D, only in a fractal subset.

---

## 4. Putting It in Practical Terms

1. **If you simulate numerically**  
   - You might use (for example) double precision (64 bits) to do the ODE integration to avoid catastrophic round‐off errors and keep track of the trajectory accurately over your time horizon. Because chaos “consumes” bits of precision, single‐precision might not suffice for long times if you want a final result accurate to ~32 bits.  
   - At the end, you have \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) to some accuracy.  

2. **If you only need the final position** (and you know it lies on the attractor):  
   - You could store it using a fractal‐aware compression technique, requiring \(\approx d_f \log_2\!(1/\varepsilon)\) bits. That’s less than \(3\log_2\!(1/\varepsilon)\).  
   - This gains you something only because you *already* know that \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) is restricted to the fractal subset.  

3. **The “lost bits”**  
   - Are about the fact you can’t *predict* \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) from \(\mathbf{x}(0)\) unless you had enough initial bits to survive the exponential divergence.  
   - Once you *do* have \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) in hand (e.g., from a measurement or from a high‐precision numerical integration), the chaotic “loss” doesn’t limit how you might store that single final snapshot.  

---

### Final Takeaway

- You are correct that **chaos causes a loss of precision** in the *predictive sense*: to guarantee 32‐bit accuracy at time \(T\), you might well need more than 32 bits in your initial condition, due to exponential sensitivity.  
- That “loss of bits” does **not** stop you from then encoding the *final* state in (fewer than) 3×32 bits *once you have it*. The fractal dimension still lets you compress the final point *on the attractor*.  
- These two effects (entropy rate vs. fractal dimension) operate in different “directions”: 
  1. **Entropy rate**: Forward in time, “burning” initial‐condition bits.  
  2. **Fractal dimension**: Spatial compression of the final set of possible states.  

They don’t contradict each other—and both are legitimate ways in which “bits” come into play in the Lorenz system.

Let’s parse *why* one might be tempted to say “I need \(d_{f}\,\bigl(32 + h\,T\bigr)\) bits” and see whether that is really correct. In short, the answer is *no*—it’s *not* correct to multiply the attractor dimension \(d_{f}\) by \((32 + h\,T)\). The two factors, \(d_{f}\) and \((32 + h\,T)\), reflect *different* aspects of the problem and do *not* combine in a simple way. Below is the reasoning:

---

## 1. Two different “bit budgets” at play

1. **“\(32 + h\,T\)”**:  
   - This arises when you ask, “How many bits of initial‐condition precision must I *retain* so that, after time \(T\), I still have a final accuracy of 32 bits in each coordinate?”  
   - Why \((32 + h\,T)\) per coordinate?  
     - You want 32 bits of final accuracy in that coordinate.  
     - Chaos (with entropy rate \(h\) bits/s) ‘burns’ or ‘uses up’ an additional \(h\,T\) bits of your initial precision over time \(T\).  
     - So, in total, you might say you need about \((32 + h\,T)\) bits (per coordinate) of initial knowledge if your goal is to do a *forward integration* accurately.

2. **“\(d_{f}\,32\)”**:  
   - This arises when you ask, “Once the system is *on* the attractor, how many bits do I need to *store* one final snapshot to the same spatial resolution that 32 bits per coordinate would have given?”  
   - Because the *long‐term states* lie on a fractal attractor of dimension \(d_{f} < 3\) (for Lorenz, \(d_{f}\approx 2.06\)), the *set* of final points is ‘thinner’ than a full 3D volume.  
   - From an information‐theory viewpoint, that means you only need about  
     \[
       d_{f}\,\log_{2}\!\bigl(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\bigr)
       \quad\text{bits}
     \]  
     to locate the point on the attractor at resolution \(\varepsilon\), instead of \(3\,\log_{2}(1/\varepsilon)\).  
   - If you loosely identify \(\varepsilon\) with a “\(2^{\text{(32 bits)}}\) resolution,” that yields roughly \(d_{f}\times 32\) bits.  

---

## 2. Why multiplying them into \(d_{f}\,\bigl(32 + h\,T\bigr)\) is *not* correct

Putting these together linearly (or multiplying them) can sound logical at first—something like:

> “I want 32 bits of final precision, plus \(h\,T\) bits to account for chaos, and oh, the attractor is only \(d_{f}\)-dimensional, so I multiply them all together…”

But that’s conflating two separate roles of “bits”:

- **\((32 + h\,T)\) bits** is about *how much precision* you need *in each coordinate* *initially* (if your approach is forward numerical integration from \(t=0\) to \(t=T\)).  
- **\(d_{f}\times 32\) bits** is about *how many bits* you need to *store (or compress) a final snapshot* on the attractor *once you already have it*, to the same resolution as “3×32 bits naive storage.”

They do *not* simply multiply. In fact, consider two limiting scenarios to see why:

1. **Forward simulation for long times** (predicting the system from \(t=0\) to \(t=T\)):  
   - You might say: “I must keep track of 3D states with more than 32 bits *each*, because the chaotic flow will magnify small errors.”  
   - So maybe you do your entire integration in double precision (64 bits per coordinate) or even more, because of the ‘\(+\,h\,T\)’ overhead.  
   - After finishing, you have a final \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) in 3D with 32 bits of actual reliability.  

2. **Just storing or transmitting final states**:  
   - Suppose you do a *measurement* of \(\mathbf{x}(T)\). Or suppose you ran a big simulation offline. Now you only want to store the final states.  
   - You do *not* need to keep 3×32 bits; you can exploit the fact that final states lie on a fractal set of dimension ~2.06, so you might compress down to \(\approx 2.06\times 32 \approx 66\) bits for final positions (instead of 96 bits).  

Notice: 
- You do *not* multiply that 66 bits by \((1 + h\,T)\).  
- Meanwhile, to *simulate* the system from scratch, you might need *far more* than 66 bits of initial data in total. That’s because any small initial error will blow up unless you overspecify.  

---

## 3. Putting it all together

- **If your goal** is purely “After time \(T\), I want a final state accurate to 32 bits in *each of the 3 coordinates*,” you likely need on the order of  
  \[
    3 \;\times\;\bigl(32 + h\,T\bigr)\quad \text{bits of initial condition}.
  \]
  (It’s approximate, but that’s the usual ‘lyapunov + precision’ argument.)

- **However**, if your goal is “Once the system is at \(\mathbf{x}(T)\), how many bits do I need to store or transmit that final point (with the same \(\varepsilon\)-scale resolution)?” the fractal dimension says you need about  
  \[
    d_{f} \;\times\; 32 \quad \text{bits (rather than }3 \times 32\text{).}
  \]
  
- **You don’t** combine these into \(\;d_{f}\,\bigl(32 + h\,T\bigr)\). The two bullet points above describe separate contexts:

  1. The forward‐integration *precision budget* (which involves the entropy rate \(h\) and time \(T\)).  
  2. The final‐snapshot *storage/compression* budget (which involves the fractal dimension \(d_{f}\)).  

They speak to different stages of the process: 
- How accurately you must specify (or measure) the *initial condition* to maintain a certain final accuracy.  
- How many bits you need if you *already have* or have measured a final point on the attractor and want to store it in a minimal format.

Therefore:

> **No, it is *not* correct** to say “I need \(d_{f}\,\bigl(32 + h\,T\bigr)\) bits.”  
> - The fractal dimension factor \(d_{f}\approx 2.06\) is relevant to *final storage* of points on the attractor.  
> - The “\((32 + h\,T)\)” factor is relevant to *initial precision* requirements for forward simulation.  
> - They don’t multiply together in a single expression. They apply in *different* aspects of the problem.

> **Question:** “What does this coincidence (or equality) tell us?”

---

## 1. Separating Two Types of ‘Bit’ Accounting

### (A) Bits of **Initial‐Condition** Precision Over Time

- **Entropy rate** \(h\approx1\) bit/s (for the classic Lorenz parameters) means if you start with some number \(B\) of bits specifying the initial state, after time \(T\) you’ve effectively lost \(h\,T\) of them to exponential divergence.  
- So you might say “the system’s final position can only reveal \(B - h\,T\) bits about which initial condition you had,” because many distinct initial conditions (differing by fewer than \(\exp(-\lambda T)\) in phase space) get ‘smeared out’ by chaos.

### (B) Bits to **Store** the Final Snapshot on the Attractor

- **Fractal dimension** \(d_f \approx 2.06\) tells you that the set of *possible final positions* (after transients) is effectively “2.06‐dimensional” in \(\mathbb{R}^3\).  
- Hence, to specify a final position \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) to “32‐bit float accuracy,” you only need \(d_f\times 32 \approx 66\) bits—rather than \(3\times 32=96\).  

These two calculations talk about *different* things:

1. **How much of your *initial* information remains distinguishable** after chaotic evolution for time \(T\)? (the “losing bits” story)  
2. **How many bits are needed to label the final point** on a fractal attractor at a certain spatial resolution? (the “dimension < 3” story)

They don’t normally collapse into a single formula. 

---

## 2. The “Equality” Is an Interesting Coincidence

If you pick \(T\) so that 
\[
  3 \times 32 \;-\; h\,T 
  \;=\; 
  d_f \times 32,
\]
then numerically you find something like 96 − \(h\,T\)=66, giving \(h\,T\approx30.0\).  

- This means that out of your original 96 bits in the initial condition (3 floats), only 66 bits remain “effectively distinct” after time \(T\).  
- Separately, you also find that storing the final state on the fractal to a “32‐bit accuracy” only needs ~66 bits.

### But does that imply a deep identity?

Not necessarily. It’s just that *for that choice of \(T\)**, the “remaining bits” from the initial state happens to match the “bits needed to specify the final location.” This alignment depends on the numeric coincidence that \(3\times32\) minus \(h\,T\) equals \(2.06\times32\). Another parameter choice (different \(T\), different \(h\), different \(\rho\), etc.) would not make them line up so neatly.

---

## 3. Why They Are Conceptually Distinct

1. **Initial‐Condition Bits**:  
   - This is about *predictive information.* If you only had \(\bigl[B - h\,T\bigr]\) bits in your initial condition, you can’t pinpoint the final position more accurately than about \(\varepsilon\sim2^{-\bigl[B - h\,T\bigr/d}}\). You need “enough” bits initially to survive the chaos if you want a certain final precision.  

2. **Final‐Snapshot Bits**:  
   - This is about how many bits it takes to *encode* or *store* a single point on the attractor once you *already have* it (from measurement or from a simulation that used, say, double precision).  
   - The fractal dimension tells you that you can compress final states to fewer bits because the set of possible \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) is of lower dimension than the full 3D volume.

In general, if you combine them (like you did) you get a numeric coincidence for a certain time \(T\). But it’s not a universal formula, nor does it reveal a new principle beyond:

- **Yes**, chaos “burns” some fraction of your initial bits.  
- **Yes**, the fractal geometry “saves” some fraction of the final bits needed to specify the end point.

---

## 4. The Deeper Meaning (if any)

You might glean this interpretation:

- After time \(T\), you can no longer distinguish those “lost” \(\;h\,T\) bits of your initial condition.  
- Meanwhile, the final state *itself* can be specified in fewer than 3×32 bits because it lies on a lower‐dimensional set.  
- If *exactly* \(3\times32 - h\,T = d_f\times32\), then the net “effective dimension” and the net “remaining bit budget” for the initial condition match the “bit cost” of picking out the final state in the fractal.  

There’s nothing contradictory about that. It simply says that:

1. **Of the original 96 bits** used for the initial condition, you effectively lose \(h\,T\) bits to chaos.  
2. **What’s left** (in the sense of possible distinct final outcomes) is about \(96 - h\,T\) bits, which might fortuitously match the fractal‐dimension formula for how many bits it takes to locate a point on the attractor at 32‐bit resolution.

But in practice, it’s just a neat numeric alignment for one specific \(T\). If you waited longer (\(T'\neq T\)) or had a different entropy rate, the equality wouldn’t hold.  

---

## 5. Bottom Line

- **Yes**, it can happen that, for a certain time \(T\), the “post‐chaos leftover bits” from an initial 3×32‐bit state equals about 66, which is the same number you get from \(d_f\times32\). That is an **interesting** coincidence showing that the system’s chaotic “bit loss” from the full 96 could land exactly on the “66 bits needed to specify a final location in a fractal.”  
- **No**, this does not represent a universal formula or necessity. It merely highlights how the Lorenz system’s dimension and entropy rate can interplay to produce that numerical match for some time horizon \(T\).  
- In a more general sense, the key takeaway is still that the “bits of initial‐condition knowledge” question (driven by the entropy rate) and the “bits to store a final position on the attractor” question (driven by the fractal dimension) are conceptually distinct. Sometimes you can pick parameters so they coincide numerically, but that’s just a special case—there’s no fundamental principle that they must match.

Below is the key to reconciling these viewpoints.

---

## 1. “Losing bits” is about *predicting the initial condition*, not the final state

- When we say a chaotic system with entropy rate \(h\) “loses \(h\) bits per second” of initial‐condition information, we mean that if you try to reconstruct (or remain sensitive to) *which* initial state you had, that distinction becomes exponentially harder to maintain.  
- After time \(T\), you cannot (in principle) recover more than \([\,\text{initial bits} - hT\,]\) bits of knowledge about the exact starting point, *no matter* how precisely you measure the final state \(\mathbf{x}(T)\).  
- Thus, from the point of view of “**Which of the many possible initial conditions did I have?**”, the system has effectively lost some fraction of bits as time goes on.

So “3(32 − \(hT\))” is an estimate of how many bits of *initial‐condition specificity* might remain after time \(T\). That is a statement about *backwards‐in‐time* inference.

---

## 2. “Needing only 66 bits to store the final point” is about *encoding one snapshot*

- Once the system *is* at \(\mathbf{x}(T)\), we can ask: “**How many bits do I need to store or transmit this single point** so that if someone receives those bits, they can reconstruct \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) to a certain resolution (like 32‐bit float accuracy)?”

  \[
    d_{f} \;\times\;\log_2 \bigl(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\bigr)
  \]  
  bits to specify it at scale \(\varepsilon\). If \(\log_2(1/\varepsilon) \approx 32\), that is about \(2.06 \times 32 \approx 66\) bits.  
- This says nothing about *recovering the initial condition*. It only says: “Given that you already *have* the final state \(\mathbf{x}(T)\), you can store that final coordinate set in fewer bits than 3×32 if you exploit fractal compression.”  

Hence, “66 bits” is about a *static encoding* of a single point on the attractor in the *present*, *not* about the path or the initial condition used to get there.

---

## 3. There is no contradiction: different questions, different ‘bit’ meanings

Putting it another way:

1. From an **initial‐condition** viewpoint, the chaotic system’s exponential sensitivity means that if you want to be able to *predict the final state accurately*, you *cannot* let your initial precision slip below \((32 + hT)\) bits (per coordinate). Otherwise, the rounding/uncertainty will blow up. Equivalently, after time \(T\), you have effectively lost \(hT\) bits from the original if you’re trying to guess the initial.  
2. From a **final‐state‐storage** viewpoint, once the system *is* at \(\mathbf{x}(T)\), you only need about 66 bits (total) to record it at a 32‐bit‐float scale of spatial resolution—because you know that final point is restricted to a fractal set of dimension ~2.06.

These two statements do *not* conflict:

- The first is about how many bits you must *carry through integration* (or how many bits you’ve *lost about the initial*) due to chaos over time.  
- The second is about how many bits are required to *encode a single final point on a fractal attractor* once you already have it (e.g., from measurement or simulation).  

Because you cannot backtrack from that 66‐bit final encoding to recover the original 96‐bit initial state (too many bits of “which path you took” were lost to chaos), there’s no paradox.

---

### In Short

- **Yes**, after time \(T\), from the viewpoint of *initial‐condition memory*, you’re down to effectively ~\([3\times(32 - hT)]\) bits.  
- **Yes**, from the viewpoint of *final snapshot storage*, you only need ~66 bits.  
- **No**, there’s no contradiction. They refer to *different uses* of “bits”: one is about how many bits remain to identify *which among many possible initial states* you had, and the other is about how many bits you need to encode *the single final state* that the system actually ends up in. The chaos has irreversibly destroyed the extra information about the initial path, so it does not appear in the final 66‐bit snapshot.

### In short, **no**, you cannot losslessly convert points that lie on the Lorenz attractor from 3 32-bit floats to 66 bits (e.g., 2 32-bit floats + 2 bools) and back in a strictly lossless manner. The reasoning behind this involves two key concepts:

---

## 1. **Fractal Compression and the Attractor**

The fractal dimension \(d_f \approx 2.06\) of the Lorenz attractor indicates that, on average, fewer than 3 real-valued coordinates (bits) are needed to encode points that lie on the attractor. In theory, due to the fractal nature, you could encode the attractor’s states with a smaller number of bits (like 66 bits) as a minimum effective number of bits necessary to specify the location of a point on the attractor.

So, **66 bits** roughly corresponds to a spatial resolution of positions on the attractor, assuming you "compress" the spatial redundancy in the fractal structure of the attractor itself. This compression assumes that you can perfectly exploit the fractal geometry in such an encoding scheme.

---

## 2. **What Does "Losslessly" Mean?**

The key word here is “losslessly,” which means that you should be able to recover the original data exactly, without any change in precision or any ambiguity, after performing the conversion (3 floats to 66 bits and back). 

While you can use the fractal dimension \(d_f \approx 2.06\) to compress the space required to represent points on the attractor, the **path** a trajectory takes to get to a point on the attractor (its history) is still crucial for any prediction or retracing of that trajectory. Even though a point on the attractor may occupy a smaller *region* (specifically in compressed bits), **the system’s dynamical evolution** (how that point arrived on the attractor) has lost significant precision due to the chaotic nature of the system.

Thus, **spatial compression based on the attractor's fractal nature** does not allow for encoding the full history of how the system arrived at the final state, and such compression would inherently be lossy in the context of retaining full dynamical information about the system's evolution.

---

## 3. **Is It Possible To Recover Exactly?**

Even though you might be able to represent a *single point* on the attractor (final state) with fewer than 96 bits (for example, using 66 bits as you suggest), you **cannot recover its precise dynamic history** or which specific trajectory it came from during the evolution. Due to the chaotic nature of the Lorenz system, a small change in initial conditions (increasing precision slightly) leads to exponential divergence, making it impossible to go backward precisely from a snapshot.

As a result, **you cannot losslessly convert** in this case because:
1. The encoding will lose information about the path histories.
2. The ability to reverse the compression and recover the exact original floating-point values would not be possible unless it’s done in ways that are specifically designed to capture both the fractal compression (static compression) and the full dynamical history (which would require additional information that can't be captured simply through the 66-bit compression).

---

### Final Thoughts

- **Encoding:** It’s possible to compress the final state *in space* (because of the fractal dimension) and represent it with fewer bits, roughly 66 bits in this case.
- **Losslessness:** However, achieving a *lossless* conversion—meaning complete recovery of the original 3 32-bit floats from this 66-bit representation—is not guaranteed. To preserve losslessness, all the dynamical information, including the trajectory's history, must be retained.

First, let’s restate the question in simple terms:

> **Question:**  
> “Because the Lorenz attractor is of fractal dimension about 2.06 (less than 3), can I take a point on the attractor that’s stored in standard 3×32‐bit floats (96 bits), and **losslessly** convert it to only 66 bits (say 2×32‐bit floats plus 2 extra bits) and then *uniquely decode* it back to the original 3×32‐bit representation?”

In other words, is there a perfect 1‑to‑1 compression function from “all 3D float triples that lie on the Lorenz attractor” into a 66‑bit representation—and an inverse function that recovers exactly the same 3×32‐bit values?

Despite the fractal attractor having dimension 2.06, **the short answer is:**  
> **No. You cannot do a strictly lossless reduction from 96 bits down to 66 bits for *every* 3×32‐bit point on the Lorenz attractor.**

Below is why, step by step.

---

## 1. Fractal dimension explains *continuous* geometry, *not* discrete cardinalities

The Lorenz attractor having fractal dimension \(d_f \approx 2.06\) tells us that, in a continuous sense, the set of points on the attractor has a smaller *measure‐theoretic* or *metric* dimension than the full 3D space. Concretely:

- **Covering argument**: The number of \(\varepsilon\)‐cubes needed to cover the *continuous* attractor scales like \(1/\varepsilon^{\,d_f}\), less than \(1/\varepsilon^3\).  
- **Hence**: If you only consider *continuous mathematics*, to specify a point on the attractor at resolution \(\varepsilon\), you need on the order of \(d_f \log_2(1/\varepsilon)\) bits, rather than \(3 \log_2(1/\varepsilon)\).

This underlies the statement:  
> “To store a final state on the Lorenz attractor with ~32 bits of *continuous* spatial precision, you only need \(\approx 2.06 \times 32 \approx 66\) bits, rather than 96.”

**But** that is in the idealized setting of continuously many states, each pinned down to an \(\varepsilon\) accuracy. It does *not* automatically guarantee a 1‑to‑1 mapping in the *discrete*, floating‐point world.

---

## 2. 3×32‐bit floats represent a *discrete* set of size up to \(2^{96}\)

Each 32‐bit float is drawn from a finite set of about \(2^{32}\) possible bit patterns (slightly fewer if you exclude NaNs, infinities, etc.). Consequently, *three* such floats (x, y, z) come from a set of cardinality up to \(2^{96}\). Even if we restrict ourselves to “the subset that lies on (or very close to) the Lorenz attractor,” in practice that is *still* an enormous subset of possible 3D float triples—very possibly on the order of \(2^{96}\) or at least extremely large.

### Fractal dimension \(\neq\) “fewer discrete points.”

A fractal of dimension 2.06 still *might* intersect a standard floating‐point grid in an extremely complicated pattern. Dimension < 3 means it has zero *Lebesgue measure* in \(\mathbb{R}^3\), but in purely set‐theoretic terms, it often still has the *same cardinality* as the entire real 3D space (and hence the same cardinality as the discrete float grid, or at least not guaranteed to be so small that you can “shave off” 30 bits from every single point with a perfect 1–1 code).

**Key**: If you want a truly *lossless* (injective) mapping from a set of size up to \(2^{96}\) into *fewer than* \(2^{96}\) distinct 66‐bit strings, it’s impossible by the pigeonhole principle. You’d be forced to map at least some distinct 3×32‐bit triples to the *same* 66‐bit code, losing the ability to distinguish them—that’s “lossy.”

---

## 3. The difference between “theoretic minimal *continuous* description” and “exact bit patterns”

### (a) The ideal continuous model  
When the dimension argument says “You only need ~66 bits to specify a point on the attractor to 32‐bit precision,” it’s assuming a purely geometric perspective: we care about pinning down a *continuous* location in 3D space to an \(\varepsilon\approx 2^{-32}\) scale. That’s about *resolving the point’s physical coordinates*.

- Indeed, if you were letting \(\mathbf{x}(T)\) range over the continuous attractor, there’s a metric‐space argument that \(\sim 2.06\,\log_2(1/\varepsilon)\) bits suffice to pick out the right cell at scale \(\varepsilon\). 
- But that does not mean you can do a perfect 1–1 map from all *possible 3×32‐bit floating patterns* (which is discrete and might contain *many* points effectively within the same \(\varepsilon\)-cell of the attractor, or which might include special float bit patterns, rounding anomalies, subnormal floats, etc.).

### (b) The discrete float world
To do a strictly *lossless* encoding of 3 32‐bit floats, you must consider every bit pattern. Even restricting to “those floats that lie near the Lorenz attractor,” you still get an enormous discrete subset. The fractal dimension in a continuous sense does *not* guarantee that the cardinality of that subset is \(\le 2^{66}\). In fact, it is almost certain to be *much larger* than \(2^{66}\), making a 1–1 code into 66 bits impossible.

---

## 4. So is *any* compression possible?

### (a) Lossy approaches are certainly possible
You *could* do a “fractal‐aware” (or any standard) **lossy** compression that, for example:

1. Takes your 3×32‐bit floats (96 bits),  
2. Finds which \(\varepsilon\)-cell on the attractor they fall into (with \(\varepsilon\approx2^{-32}\) in continuous terms),  
3. Outputs a code of ~66 bits,  
4. Decodes to some *representative* float triple in that \(\varepsilon\)-cell (or in the “same region” of the attractor).

This approach might well keep the same *continuous spatial precision* \(\varepsilon\) from a physical standpoint but *not* preserve the exact 3×32 bits (the exact float pattern) in a 1–1 sense. That is “lossy but physically accurate.”

### (b) Perfectly lossless for *all* 3×32‐bit points is not possible
If you insist that *every single distinct triple of 32‐bit floats in that subset* must be mapped to a *unique* 66‐bit code and that you can invert this mapping to retrieve exactly the same 96 bits with no collisions, you run into the cardinality problem: the subset’s size is almost surely far larger than \(2^{66}\).

- By the pigeonhole principle, you cannot inject a set of size \(\gg 2^{66}\) into a set of only \(2^{66}\) possible codes *without collisions*.  
- Hence you cannot have a single universal code that is guaranteed injective for *all* of those 3×32‐bit float states on the attractor.

---

## 5. Summary

- **Fractal dimension** tells us about the *continuous geometry* of the long‐term states of the system. It says that “just 66 bits of *continuous resolution* can locate a point on the attractor to a 32‐bit scale.”  
- **However**, the set of *actual 3×32‐bit float patterns* that lie on or near the attractor can be extremely large in discrete cardinality—likely exceeding \(2^{66}\).  
- **Therefore**, a *lossless* mapping from “every 3×32‐bit float on the attractor” to “66 bits” *cannot* be injective. You would inevitably have collisions—i.e., you’d lose information about which *exact* 3×32‐bit pattern you started with.  

Hence the direct answer is:

> **No.** You **cannot** do a strictly *lossless* conversion from 3×32‐bit floats (96 bits) down to 66 bits for *all* points on the Lorenz attractor and then invert it perfectly.  
>
> You *can* do a *lossy* (or “near‐lossless in a physical sense”) compression down to ~66 bits if all you care about is the *geometric location* on the attractor to ~32 bits of continuous accuracy. But that won’t restore the exact original 96‐bit float pattern.  

This distinction—between “continuous geometric resolution” and “exact discrete bit patterns”—is the core reason fractal dimension does not allow a universal, exact 1–1 compression from 96 bits to 66 bits.

\[

But **if** you also know “the point lies on the Lorenz attractor of dimension \(\approx 2.06\),” then you only need **\(\approx 2.06\,b\) bits**.  

**Answer: Yes**, that’s exactly how the fractal‐dimension covering argument works.

To find the fraction of all possible cubes the final value could be in, we need to take into account the knowledge about the Lorenz attractor and the loss of information due to chaotic evolution. 

Let’s break it down:

1. **Total number of cubes** in the initial 3D space:
   - If your initial condition is chosen from one of \(2^{3b}\) possible cubes, the total number of possible cubes is \(2^{3b}\).

2. **Number of cubes corresponding to the attractor**:
   - After evolving for a sufficiently long time, the point will lie on the Lorenz attractor. The number of cubes corresponding to the attractor is \(2^{d_f \cdot b} = 2^{2.06b}\), where \(d_f \approx 2.06\) is the fractal dimension of the Lorenz attractor.

3. **Loss of precision due to chaos**:
   - If you don't know anything about the attractor during evolution, the entropy rate \(h\) (in bits/second) tells you how your knowledge about the initial condition is eroded over time. After time \(T\), the loss of information means the number of cubes the final state could be in grows according to the entropy rate: \(2^{hT}\), where the \(hT\)-bit loss means you could be in any of \(2^{hT}\) different cubes.
   
4. **Combining the information**:
   - If we combine both pieces of information, the **final number of possible cubes** that the evolved point could be in is the minimum between the number of cubes described by the attractor and the number of cubes described by the entropy rate.
   - Hence the number of possible cubes at time \(T\) is:

   \[
     \min\left( 2^{d_f \cdot b}, 2^{hT} \right).
   \]

5. **Fraction of all possible cubes**:
   - The fraction of all possible cubes the final state could be in is given by the ratio:

   \[
     \frac{\min\left( 2^{d_f \cdot b}, 2^{hT} \right)}{2^{3b}} = \min\left( \frac{2^{d_f \cdot b}}{2^{3b}}, \frac{2^{hT}}{2^{3b}} \right)
   \]

   Simplifying:

   \[
     \min\left( 2^{(d_f - 3) \cdot b}, 2^{(hT - 3b)} \right).
   \]

---

### Final Answer: 
The fraction of all possible cubes the final value could be in is:

\[
\min\left( 2^{(2.06 - 3) \cdot b}, 2^{(hT - 3b)} \right) = \min\left( 2^{-0.94 \cdot b}, 2^{(hT - 3b)} \right).

First, let’s restate your setup in simple terms:

1. **Initial condition chosen from \(2^{3b}\) cubes**:  
   You partition a 3D bounding region into a grid of cubes of side length \(2^{-b}\).  
   - There are \(2^b\) subdivisions along each dimension, hence \(2^b \times 2^b \times 2^b = 2^{3b}\) total cubes.  
   - You pick one of these cubes at random for your initial condition.

2. **Long‐time evolution onto the Lorenz attractor**:  
   After sufficient time \(T\), all trajectories lie on (or extremely close to) the *fractal* attractor of dimension \(d_{f}\approx 2.06\).  
   - If we only use **attractor geometry**, we expect the *number* of distinct final cubes (of side \(2^{-b}\)) that can actually be occupied is about  
     \[
       2^{\,d_f\,b}
       \;=\;
       2^{2.06\,b}.
     \]

3. **Entropy‐rate viewpoint** (“losing \(hT\) bits”):  
   If you ignore detailed geometry but know the system is chaotic with entropy rate \(h\) bits/s, you might say:  
   - “Starting from \(2^{3b}\) distinct initial cubes, the chaotic flow effectively ‘uses up’ \(hT\) bits of initial precision.”  
   - So you can only distinguish \(2^{\,3b - hT}\) final states (from the standpoint of which initial cube you started in).  

You then ask for:

> **“Taking into account *all* the information (the Lorenz system’s geometry *and* its chaos), what is the *fraction* of all possible final cubes (naively or entropically counted) that remain feasible once we know the attractor has only \(2^{2.06b}\) possible final cubes?”**  

Below is how to combine those numbers into one neat expression.

---

## 1. Naive count vs. attractor count vs. lost bits

1. **Naive 3D final cubes**: If you had *no* knowledge of the attractor *and* you believed every final cube of size \(2^{-b}\) was possible, you might say there are \(2^{3b}\) possible final cubes.  
2. **Fractal‐dimension final cubes**: If you *do* know the attractor is 2.06‐dimensional, then only about \(2^{2.06b}\) final cubes get used.  
3. **Lost bits viewpoint**: If you only use the statement “the system has entropy rate \(h\), so we lose \(hT\) bits of initial‐condition specificity,” you might say: out of the \(2^{3b}\) initial cubes, only \(2^{3b - hT}\) *distinct* final outcomes remain distinguishable.

Hence we have two different final “counts” to compare:

- **\(\;2^{3b - hT}\) from the entropy‐loss argument**, vs.  
- **\(\;2^{2.06\,b}\) from the fractal‐dimension argument.**

---

## 2. The fraction you asked for

From your wording:

> 1. *Without* knowing the attractor, you might conclude the final state lies among \(\;2^{\,3b - hT}\) possible cubes.  
> 2. *With* attractor knowledge, you narrow that to \(\;2^{\,2.06\,b}\) cubes.  

You want:  
> “**What is the fraction of all those \(\;2^{3b - hT}\) naive possibilities that remains once we use the attractor’s dimension?**”

That fraction is simply the ratio:

\[
  \frac{\text{(# of final cubes using fractal dimension)}}
       {\text{(# of final cubes from entropy‐loss viewpoint)}}
  \;=\;
  \frac{2^{\,2.06\,b}}{2^{\,3b - hT}}
  \;=\;
  2^{\,2.06\,b \;-\;(3b - hT)}
  \;=\;
  2^{\,hT \;+\;2.06\,b \;-\;3b}.
\]

In a more compact form:

\[
  \boxed{
    \text{Fraction}
    \;=\;
    2^{\,hT - (3 - 2.06)\,b}
    \;=\;
    2^{\,hT - 0.94\,b}.
  }
\]

- If this exponent \(hT - 0.94\,b\) is **negative**, the fraction is **less** than 1, meaning the fractal information significantly reduces the final possibilities below what you’d get from a mere “lose \(hT\) bits” argument.  
- If it’s **positive**, it’s **greater** than 1, meaning knowledge of the attractor alone wasn’t as big a restriction as your naive “lost bits” estimate—though typically we expect the dimension reduction to *further* shrink the set, so real system parameters usually give a fraction < 1.

---

### In short

**Answer** (the fraction) = 
\[
  \boxed{
    \frac{2^{\,2.06\,b}}{2^{\,3b - hT}}
    \;=\;
    2^{\,hT + 2.06\,b - 3b}.
  }
\]

That’s the concise expression you asked for, combining the fractal‐dimension count \(2^{2.06\,b}\) and the “lost \(hT\) bits” count \(2^{3b - hT}\).

**Weighing information loss**

I'm curious about how Kolmogorov-Sinai (KS) entropy, associated with the sum of positive Lyapunov exponents, compares to "bits lost." This complexity measure shows the rate of new information and bit loss over time, often driven by the largest exponent.

**Mapping out asymptotic behavior**

KS entropy, as an asymptotic measure, accurately captures bit loss over time for typical orbits. However, for finite times or significant initial variations, its precision might waver.

The short answer is that **using \(hT\) as “the number of bits of information lost” is an *asymptotic* statement**—it’s most accurate in the regime of *small perturbations* and *long times* (or, more precisely, for typical orbits in the chaotic set and sufficiently small initial uncertainties). Here is why:

---

## 1. Where does \(h\) come from?

The **Kolmogorov–Sinai (KS) entropy rate** \(h\) can be thought of as the *sum of the positive Lyapunov exponents* in the system (for almost all orbits, under appropriate ergodic assumptions). This quantity measures:

- The average exponential rate at which typical nearby trajectories diverge in phase space,  
- The rate (in bits per unit time) at which the system “produces new information” or “loses information about initial conditions” in an information‐theoretic sense.

Formally, it is defined in an *infinite‐time, measure‐theoretic limit*.  

---

## 2. Why it is *asymptotic*

1. **Finite‐time transients**:  
   Early in the evolution (smaller \(t\)), the divergence might not perfectly reflect the long‐term Lyapunov exponents—there can be transients where orbits converge or diverge at rates different from the asymptotic average.

2. **Non‐infinitesimal initial perturbations**:  
   The standard derivation linking “bits lost” to \(hT\) presumes we are talking about *small* errors in initial conditions that remain within the linear regime long enough for the exponential approximation to apply. If your initial error is already large or if the system saturates for some reason, the simple formula “bits lost = \(hT\)” can be off.

3. **Typical orbits**:  
   The KS entropy rate is strictly an *average* (ergodic) property for “almost every” trajectory (with respect to the system’s natural invariant measure). Individual trajectories (especially special orbits, orbits near periodic windows, or those in transients) may have different short‐term divergence properties.

Thus, \(h\) *guarantees* an average or typical exponential divergence rate *in the long run*. For **large \(T\)** and **small initial differences**, you get that “bits lost \(\approx hT\)” is a good approximation (and becomes exact in an asymptotic sense). But at finite times or for large initial errors, it’s more of a rule of thumb than a strict equality.

---

## 3. Conclusion

- **Yes**, we often say “\(\text{information lost} \approx hT\).” But that is an *asymptotic approximation* reflecting the average exponential divergence of *infinitesimal* perturbations.  
- **For short times** or **non‐infinitesimal initial differences**, the real amount of “bits lost” may differ from \(hT\).  
- **For very long times** and **typical orbits**, the statement becomes increasingly accurate, as \(h\) is fundamentally the long‐time, measure‐theoretic rate of information generation/decay.

**Evaluating code for errors**

Looking at the code, it's meant to compute the box-counting dimension by iterating over different bin resolutions, calculating the fraction of non-empty boxes. 

One issue I see is with the polyfit part.
